utterances: Way beyond.
The American who took the bronze in this race, Leah Smith - a distant bronze - said we'll probably be seeing Katie Ledecky in the 2024 Games.
How old will you and I be by then (laughter)?
I don't want to even think about it.
I mean, when it's - right.
That's two Olympics away.
Swimming aficionados now are probably going to correct me here.
But, you know, David, I can't think of a female swimmer as dominant or as potentially dominant.
You know, the men have had Michael Phelps, Mark Spitz - guys who needed wheelbarrows to hold all their medals.
Yeah.
I can't think of a similar woman until now.
Katie Ledecky is special.
That medal haul is going to come over the coming years.
You know, it's just going to get better and better, I think.
Well, special indeed.
Well, let's turn to Michael Phelps now.
He was in the really hotly contested 4x100-meter freestyle relay.
And...
Yeah.
...I mean, it was a - quite a night for him too.
It was.
You know, if ever an athlete could settle and rest on considerable laurels, it's him.
Going into the race, he had 22 total medals, 18 gold, most of all time.
But man, he was a man on fire.
He swam the second leg.
When the starter touched the wall and Phelps dived in, the U.S.
was behind.
Hundred meters later, U.S.
was ahead, and the Americans kept the lead the rest of the way.
They beat their archrival France, which won the race four years ago at the London Olympics.
And Phelps says he swam the fastest 100 freestyle in his career.
That's saying a lot because it's a special career.
Yeah.
It sounds like the atmosphere last night that you were taking in - I mean, not a swim even, more like a like a Roman coliseum or something.
(Laughter) It was amazing.
As soon as the teams came onto the pool deck, the crowd started roaring.
And I mean roaring.
This was a hugely anticipated race because it was wide open.
The U.S., France, Australia were considered medal favorites with no real good bet on who'd win.
And afterwards, even Phelps talked about the electricity.
Here he is.
(SOUNDBITE OF ARCHIVED RECORDING)
I was going to say, when I was on the block, I honestly felt my heart was going to explode out of my chest.
Like, I was so hyped tonight and so excited.
And to hear the stands as loud it was - I mean, that was wild.
I don't know if I've ever heard something like that at a meet.
You know, David, athletes talk about blocking out the noise, the distractions.
Well, it sounds like Phelps and his buddies got high octane fuel from that crowd.
It sure does.
All right, NPR's Tom Goldman covering the Olympics for us in Rio.
Thanks, Tom.
You're welcome.
We do not have a firm count yet for the number of people killed in the weekend's earthquake in Ecuador.
But the government says it is now well over 400.
That number, the death toll, is expected to grow.
Let's turn now to reporter Julia Symmes Cobb.
She is in Pedernales.
It's a rustic beach town along the Ecuadorian coast that was one of the hardest hit communities in the country.
Julia, good morning to you.
Hi, David.
Can you just describe to us what you've been seeing in this city?
Well, 80 percent of buildings here in Pedernales were damaged somehow by the quake.
So many people have lost their homes, lost their businesses, lost any worldly possessions.
So a lot of people have been made homeless.
And people were sleeping on the streets on mattresses or in hammocks, whatever they could sort of rig up.
The open spaces in the town, like the central square, had dozens of people sleeping in it.
People are afraid to be in buildings.
And also, they are afraid of another quake.
So many people were restless, wandering the streets at night.
There's obviously a great need for food and water, as well as medical supplies.
And are rescue workers still finding people who survived this in the rubble somewhere?
There have been some rescues of living victims here in Pedernales.
But most the rescues now are pulling out remains from the wreckage.

Well, between last August, when the indictment was handed over to the Jamaican government with the extradition request, our government has been trying to stall Coke's extradition by claiming that the evidence collected against him was done in breach of Jamaica's Interception of Communications Act.

The pressure exerted by sections of Jamaican society and the Jamaican diaspora came down hard on the government's shoulders and forced our prime minister, Bruce Golding, to announce that after eight months, the extradition proceedings will began against Coke.
This irked his supporters.
Why does the U.S.
want Christopher Coke?
He's being extradited for intent to import and distribute large amounts of cocaine in the United States.
He's also wanted for gun-running.
And he faces a potential life sentence.
Yes, and forfeiture of his assets.
He comes from a dynastic family.
His father was much-revered, also.
Revered and feared.
What does the Coke name mean in Jamaica?
The Coke name is a very powerful name in Jamaica in terms of the underground, with the, for want of a better term, the common man.
He is revered by people in the lower strata of society, and he's well-connected with people in the upper strata of society.
What kinds of things does he do?
They have come out publicly to say that he provides money for their kids to go to school.
He provides them a source of livelihood.
He's very kind.
They say he's next to God, and they will die for him.
We're talking to you in the afternoon right now.
What are the concerns as night falls in Kingston?
Well, people are on tenterhooks.
People are edgy.
On one hand, you have the police and their opponents, the criminals, waging a battle in the streets.
On the other hand, theyre - the majority of the population are being held hostage.
There's no freedom of movement.
So this entire scenario has been bad for my country in a multiplicity of ways.
Mr.
Walker, thank you very much for your time.
You're welcome.
Karyl Walker is an online news editor for the Jamaica Observer.
The great Russian writer Vasily Aksyonov has died.
Ten years ago on this program, Aksyonov read from his novel, ""The Winter's Hero,"" about Soviet labor camps.
(Reading) It didn't matter what you took, a string of sausages or gold bars, to the camps were sent even the bumblers who showed up late for work.
In other words, who committed a crime that amounted to sabotage of reconstruction.
On the whole, it's hard to argue there was order.
Reviewer Alan Cheuse knew Aksyonov and has this remembrance.
I wasn't surprised to hear of Aksyonov's death.
Ever since the extraordinary Russian novelist had suffered a debilitating stroke about a year ago, I was prepared for such news.
I had known Vasya Aksyonov for nearly 20 years, first meeting him after he'd been forcibly exiled from his beloved country in 1980.
He was giving a talk to a large committee of academics in an interview for a post at George Mason University.
Interviewing Aksyonov, would you interview Tolstoy, interview Thomas Hardy, interview Melville?
No, you'd count your blessings if they said they'd be willing to stand in front of your students and talk about literature and life.
So, here came Aksyonov, a chunky man with an engaging squint of a smile, built like a wrestler.
A trained pulmonary specialist who smoked up a storm, muttering and growling in his low, heavily accented English about literature and life, et cetera, as he often punctuated his speech, et cetera.
One of the committee members asked me if I thought he was good.
Of course, she hadn't read him.
She could barely understand him, she said.
Not good, great, I muttered and growled.
Yes.
I saw Vasya on and off over the next decade and more.

I loved his work, especially his Moscow trilogy, ""Generations of Winter,"" in which he embraces all sorts of modernist literary techniques to tell the story of life under Stalin, for heroes and complex villains alike.
It's the great Russian novel of the post-war period.
